Following is a brief description.* Ticket cashing machine are not operating all over the floor with few exceptions. Dollar change is not tender to the customers.* Majority of the ATM machine is operated by the casino and the customers received no cash but a receipt to take to the cashier with more than a hour long wait with heavy duty fee.* Cafeteria menu prices are extremely high comparing to other casinos.* after the pandemic, stop altogether complementary drinks on floor.I hope the management will not take it as a criticism, but suggestion for improving the daily operation which will bring more revenue and hence increasing the stock price as well.

I've been following penn closely for a few months, I think this could be a great entrance point. Q2 was a lot better than I thought it would be. I remember the PE on yahoo above 300, not its 24 with a lower forward PE as well. They do have a lot of debt but in line with industry. I see this as a hybrid between traditional casinos and online gambling. I think penn having barstool really sets them apart from the other companies in the industry. I am not a huge barstool fan, but they have a religious following and with icasino becoming a legal in more states, I think that could drive revenue more than expected. They had a solid cash flow statement as well. Penn has already lost like half its value from its highs, I do not see it going lower, with a low forward PE. I think they are in better financial position today then when they were above 100s. What are some thoughts?

Let's do an exercise on PENN's cash situation.At the end of the 1st qtr. they had $2.062 billion in cash during the second qtr they sucessfully added another $300 million giving them $2.362 billion. They just announced that they are selling $400 million more giving them cash of $2,762 billion.Unlike many of the other gaming companies the are not losing money and and burning cash. They as any operating company need cash for operations. As the end of 2019 they had $437 million in cash. As a conservative estimate let's say the need $462 million. That gives them $2.3 billion in excess.My question is why. Are they planning an acquisition?
